item.title: U-Turning Oil Supertankers Cross Hormuz After Avoiding It
item.description: Two supertankers, each capable of hauling about 2 million barrels of crude, headed through the Hormuz shipping strait at the mouth of the Persian gulf, having performed U-turns in the past 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz. Photographer: Kaveh Kazemi/Getty Images

item.title: China Tightens Fentanyl Controls in Goodwill Gesture to Trump
item.description: China moved to tighten controls over two chemicals that can be used to make fentanyl, in an apparent olive branch to the US that may help maintain their fragile trade truce.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: A confiscated package of Fentanyl is seen at the San Ysidro Port of Entry on October 2, 2019 in San Ysidro, California.

item.title: Iran Says Nuclear Arms-Control Treaty Irreparably Damaged by US
item.description: Iran said US strikes on its nuclear sites over the weekend have delivered an “irreparable blow” to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, rendering it ineffective.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Iran’s IAEA envoy Reza Najafi in Vienna on June 23. Photographer: Joe Klamar/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: What Mike Tyson and the Bond Market Can Teach Trump on Debt
item.description: Treasury buyers will be the ultimate arbiters on whether MAGA math adds up.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

item.title: NYC to Vote During Heatwave as Cost, Crime Dominate Mayoral Race
item.description: The outcome of the race could help define the path forward for the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos

media:content.media:description: The Art and Design High School during early voting for New York City’s Democratic primary for mayor.

item.title: Home to Trump Golf Resort Faces Growing Fear Amid Deportation Policy Changes
item.description: Christi Fraga, the mayor of Doral, Florida, is being bombarded with questions about US immigration rules she doesn’t know how to answer.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Zerpa, Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Doral Mayor Christi Fraga speaks during a City Council meeting in April 2025.

item.title: Putin May Gain From Trump’s Focus on Iran
item.description: With Trump’s attention elsewhere, Russia’s leader may get an increasingly free hand to pursue his war aims.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin during a plenary session at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum on June 20, in a photo released by Russian state media. Photographer: Ivan Sekretarev/AP Photo

item.title: Thai Leader Defies Calls to Quit as Border Spat Escalates
item.description: Thai leader Paetongtarn Shinawatra looks poised to ride out a political crisis engulfing her government, with a cabinet revamp to keep her coalition intact and a tougher stance in a simmering border dispute with Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: How Trump’s Spurning of European Allies Is Transforming NATO
item.description: NATO is in turmoil just as the military alliance confronts the deadliest conflict on its doorstep since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: US President Trump at the 2018 NATO Summit. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Ivory Coast’s Ouattara Delays Decision on Fourth Term Bid
item.description: Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara surprised members of the ruling party by deferring a decision on whether he will seek a fourth term in October elections.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Alassane Ouattara Photographer: Denis Balibouse/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Malaysian PM Anwar’s Popularity Rises Even as Growth Slows
item.description: Support for Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim rose as he crossed the midpoint of his five-year term amid political stability.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, leaves a meeting during the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, May 26, 2025. Southeast Asian leaders start two days of talks from Monday, seeking to deepen ties with China and Gulf nations, and mitigate the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes.

item.title: Senate Readies Tax Bill for Vote With Holdouts Threatening Delay
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tax-and-spending agenda is nearing a climatic vote in the Senate this week in the wake of air strikes on Iran, which risk embroiling the US in a prolonged Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Romania Pledges to Tackle Deficit as Government to Be Approved
item.description: Romania’s new ruling coalition pledged to approve a detailed plan to reduce the European Union’s widest budget deficit with a raft of proposed tax increases and spending cuts as they prepare to vote in a new government.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Ilie Bolojan Photographer: Magali Cohen/AFP/Getty Image

item.title: China Rips Trump’s Iran Attack in First Comment Since US Hit
item.description: China criticized the US strike on Iranian nuclear facilities and reiterated that it’s willing to join international efforts to restore peace in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Yian Lee

item.title: Iran’s Payback Threat for US Strike Keeps World Powers on Alert
item.description: Iran vowed retaliation and kept up attacks on Israel following the US strikes on its nuclear facilities over the weekend, fueling fears of a wider war in the Middle East and rattling global markets.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: The Isfahan Nuclear Technology and Research Center after recent airstrikes on June 22. Source: Satellite image ©2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: Iran Says US Is Now Directly in War, Response Will Come

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Air Force Gen. Dan Caine with Pete Hegseth at the Pentagon on June 22. Photographer: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images North America

item.title: Japan’s LDP Suffers Bruising Loss in Tokyo Before National Vote
item.description: Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party suffered its worst-ever result in a Tokyo metropolitan election, losing its spot as the biggest political force on the assembly less than a month before voters deliver a verdict on Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s premiership in a national vote.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, Japan's prime minister, at the Nikkei Future of Asia forum in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The forum will continue through May 30.

item.title: More Deaths in Kyiv as Russia Hits Civilian Infrastructure
item.description: Russia unleashed another massive missile and drone strike on Kyiv that killed at least six people, as Moscow steps up its aerial attacks on civilian infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Firefighters tackle a blaze at an apartment building after a Russian attack, in Kyiv, on June 23. Photographer: Efrem Lukatsky/AP Photo

item.title: Pakistan Condemns US Strikes in Iran While Embracing Trump
item.description: Pakistan condemned the US’s bombing of nuclear sites in Iran while at the same time taking steps to build stronger ties with President Donald Trump, suggesting limits to how far Islamabad will go in supporting Tehran in the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider, Jon Herskovitz

media:content.media:description: Protesters demonstrate against the US and Israel, in Karachi, Pakistan, on June 22.

item.title: EU and Canada Prepare to Sign Security Pact Ahead of NATO Summit
item.description: The European Union and Canada are expected to sign a security and defense partnership on Monday at a summit that will kick off a range of discussions about how they can work closer together.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney arrives in Brussels on June 22. Photographer: Sean Kilpatrick/AP Photo

item.title: Spain Wins Exemption From NATO’s 5% Defense Spending Goal
item.description: Spain obtained an exemption from NATO’s ambitious defense spending target of 5% of GDP after several days of diplomatic wrangling that drew scorn from Donald Trump, right before leaders of the military alliance gather on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: A Spanish Air Force Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jet on the runway during a NATO exercise.

item.title: Japan Says No US Demand for Defense Spending Worth 3.5% of GDP
item.description: Japan denied a report that the US directly asked Tokyo to raise its defense spending to 3.5% of annual gross domestic product, with its top government spokesman saying that the amount of spending was less important than how Japan raises its military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Sarah Hilton

media:content.media:description: The Japan Self Defense Forces. Photographer: Keith Bedford/Bloomberg

item.title: What Turning a Blind Eye to Deviant Behavior Is Doing to London
item.description: The city’s mayor, Sadiq Khan, needs to take growing disorder on the streets more seriously.
item.dc:creator: Adrian Wooldridge

media:content.media:description: Graffiti covers part of a train carriage on the Bakerloo Line on June 16, 2025, in London, England.

item.title: Britain's HS2 Is Frankenstein's Railway
item.description: How a high-speed rail project became a fiscal monster.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brooker

media:content.media:description: An aerial view the HS2 Curzon No.2 Viaduct on June 18, 2025, in Birmingham, England.

item.title: UBS Downgrades Thai Stocks to Neutral as Political Woes Weigh
item.description: UBS Group AG strategists downgraded Thai stocks to neutral from overweight, citing recent political uncertainty which could impact policy direction and investor sentiment.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng

item.title: Philippine VP Duterte Criticizes Marcos for Leaning Towards US
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte slammed President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. for leaning towards the US, while signaling openness to friendlier ties with China.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF’s Georgieva Warns of Broader Risks From US Strikes on Iran
item.description: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the US strikes on Iran could potentially have broader impacts beyond energy channels, as global uncertainty escalates.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva in Tokyo on June 23.

item.title: A Weakened Iran Can Still Inflict Pain on the US — and the World
item.description: When the dust settled on Iran’s nuclear sites on Sunday after a US bombing raid that President Donald Trump said had “totally obliterated” its atomic program, one thing was still missing: its highly enriched uranium, which international authorities haven't seen for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Portraits of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and late leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, as demonstrators protest US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities, in downtown Tehran on June 22.

item.title: US Strikes Iran in Operation Midnight Hammer
item.description: On today’s Big Take podcast: what’s next for the Israel-Iran war after 14 US “bunker busters.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Holder, David Fox

media:content.media:description: A B-2 Spirit approaches a KC-135 Stratotanker in 2019. Source: Staff Sgt. Jordan Castelan/U.S. Air Force

item.title: US Issues ‘Worldwide Caution’ for Americans After Attack on Iran
item.description: The US State Department issued a “Worldwide Caution” alert for American citizens, flagging the potential of travel disruptions and demonstrations following the US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Bill Faries

media:content.media:description: Photo by Milos Bicanski/Getty Images) Photographer: Milos Bicanski/Getty Images Europe
